Aicha,

It depends on what you are doing.

Often the comparison done by loading the entire XML file into a String and then comparing them in the usual
assertEquals() manner.  This should work okay as long as the same XML processor produced the file.  If different XML
processors are involved you may have issues relating to whitespace, line terminators and attribute ordering that makes
this method impractical.  There is a utility called dgnorm.exe that is part of the XSLTMark benchmark that will
normalise these factors to allow you to compare output from different processors (see:
http://www.datapower.com/XSLTMark/).

There is also a tool from IBM's Alphaworks site, XML Diff and Merge, that can be executed as a command and will produce
an xml file summarising the differences between files.

Not much JUnit stuff here but it is doable.

I'm looking at putting something together that will do this from a pair pre-existing DOM tree (or a file or a
combination of these) but I'm only just starting this now.  Let's see how I go using my spare time over the next couple
months.

Good luck,

Scott
